awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Novel Approaches for Mining Large and Complex Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This CAREER project includes an integrated research, education, and outreach program that focusses on the development of novel methods for mining large, complex networks.  Networks (graphs) are ubiquitous in real-world applications. Although successful, the methodology development for network analytics is still in its early stage. This project addresses fundamental questions essential to the advancement of large and complex network analytics. These challenges are driven by real-world applications in social, biological, and medical domains. The research plan is complemented by a comprehensive education and outreach plan focussed on three elements: (1) the development of new interdisciplinary courses; (2) direct undergraduate involvement in the research projects; and (3) outreach activities including the STEM program targeting K-12 schools. Underrepresented students will be encouraged to participate in this project. 

The research goal of the project is to significantly extend the reliability and efficiency of large network analysis. The project has three research aims. (1) Develop novel memory-based random walk proximity measures that can effectively capture the similarity between nodes. Proximity measure is of fundamental importance for many advanced network analysis tasks. A rigorous theoretical foundation will be provided for the developed measures. (2) Study the dual-network model and its applications. The dual-network model has a wide range real-world applications. The specific problem of cross-network node set query will be investigated in the project. Both numerical and algorithmic approaches will be explored. (3) Design robust and flexible multi-network algorithms for clustering and ranking. The focus will be on a novel multi-network model, a network of networks, which allows us to integrate domain similarities to improve the performance of the algorithms.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Many real-world applications can be modeled as graph-structured data or networks. In these applications, nodes represent data objects and edges represent certain relationships between the nodes. Analyzing network data has attracted intensive research interest. For example, social networks, molecular structures and knowledge graphs all require utilizing the rich connection information among nodes.

In this project, we developed a set of new algorithms and models for analyzing large and complex networks. One fundamental problem we studied is how to effectively measure the proximity between different nodes. Most of the previous random walk measures assume that the next step of the random surfer only depends on the current node and is independent of the previous step. To address the limitation of existing measures, we developed memory-based random walk measures, which take the previous step into consideration. We studied the theoretical foundation of these newly developed measures and designed efficient algorithms to compute them. Another direction we investigated is the dual-network work model. A dual-network is a pair of networks consisting of nodes from two related domains. A common computational problem in many applications is that, given a set of input nodes in one network, find a set of related nodes in another network. We explored both algorithmic and numerical approaches to address this problem. A more general data model we studied is the network of networks model, where each node in the main network can be further represented as another network.  Based on this model, we developed robust clustering and ranking methods that can incorporate all relevant information to improve the performance of the algorithms. The research results have been published in top data mining and machine learning venues.


Last Modified: 03/02/2023
Modified by: Xiang Zhang
